channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Electronic switching of topology in LaSbTe
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 12 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02396-3

This study shows that the nodal loop topology in LaSbxTe2−x can be controlled by chemical substitution and electron doping. The reversible opening and closing of a gap larger than 400 meV in the nodal loop enables on-demand switching of topology.
item.dc:title: Electronic switching of topology in LaSbTe
item.dc:creator: J. Bannies

item.title: Electrical control of silicon T centres
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02415-3

Electrical control of silicon T centres
item.dc:title: Electrical control of silicon T centres
item.dc:creator: Amos Martinez

item.title: Facets as the key to stable perovskites
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02406-4

An intermediate phase steers the preferential {100} orientation of evaporated perovskites, securing long-term device stability for perovskite photovoltaics.
item.dc:title: Facets as the key to stable perovskites
item.dc:creator: Yabing Qi
Jia Liang

item.title: Mechanical non-reciprocity programmed by shear jamming in soft composite solids
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 07 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02407-3

Using the shear jamming transition within soft composite solids, non-reciprocal mechanics are achieved for the asymmetric spatiotemporal control of soft materials.
item.dc:title: Mechanical non-reciprocity programmed by shear jamming in soft composite solids
item.dc:creator: Chang Xu
Shuaihu Wang
Hong Wang
Xu Liu
Zemin Liu
Yiqiu Zhao
Wenqi Hu
Qin Xu

item.title: Non-invasive bioinert room-temperature quantum sensor from silicon carbide qubits
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 06 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02382-9

Alkene-terminated silicon carbide surfaces are proposed as a room-temperature divacancy spin qubit quantum sensor suitable for bioimaging and nanoscale nuclear spin sensing.
item.dc:title: Non-invasive bioinert room-temperature quantum sensor from silicon carbide qubits
item.dc:creator: Pei Li
Ji-Yang Zhou
